ygData.subject: Re: Malachite in Qeynos? NO MORE?!?!
ygData.msgSnippet: Obviously never sell to NPC s what you can sell to other players.  With the exception of armor though there is minimal demand for items created by the other
ygData.messageBody:
Obviously never sell to NPC's what you can sell to other players. With
the exception of armor though there is minimal demand for items created
by the other skills.

When you finish pondering a trade and finally decide upon one you will
find how utterly pointless it is until you have invested about 200pp in
it (with the case of smithing or jewelry) or completely pointless
(brewing, pottery, etc.).
-----Original Message-----
From: Vincent.Archer
Sent: Monday, May 10, 1999 11:40 AM
To: .EQ.Magic
Cc: Vincent.Archer
Subject: Re: [_EQ_Magic] Malachite in Qeynos? NO MORE?!?!

From: Vincent Archer <Vincent.Archer@...>

According to michael.andersen@...:
> economy that makes EQ interesting. In fact they even note in the
> instructions that certain vendors will pay more for you goods then
> others (town vendors versus vendors out in the wilderness). What I

Tip 1: Sell in town rather than outside

Tip 2: Sell to vendors that /con you better (neutral as opposed to
threatiningly or some such)

Tip 3: Sell in your guild (they /con warmly, usually)

Tip 4: Sell in your home area

Tip 5: Due to a bug, if you're a high elf, sell in Wood elfland; they
like you better there :)

> sell for a profit. While I can appreciate Verant's attempt to create
a
> totally player driven economy; one should be able to make a minimal
> living dealing with NPC's to some extent (with the exception of
> fishing).

That's not the intent. Verant didn't want to repeat the Ultima Offline
experience.

> In particular the creation of magic jewelry kills me. I create
> something for 5.5PP, sell it to a vendor for 4.5PP, he in turn marks
it
> up to 98PP. You should at least be able to recover your initial
> investment on these trade skills (not to mention the fact all the
money
> lost on failures).

Note that none of the items players create exist otherwise (i.e. you
can't
make straight leather, chain, plate, or anything else). Which means the
market for these items isn't supposed to be the NPC, it's supposed to be
the OTHER players. Never sell to NPCs what you can sell to players.

Ultannis, Wizard starting to ponder what trade skill he should take,
apart from its fishing hobby whenever waiting for that damned boat
between Butcherblock and Freeport :)

(hmmm, rogues get the poison trade skill, shamans alchemy, enchanter are
naturals for jewelry... but what about the other mage classes... Would
look funny for a Wizard to take smithing for a hobby)
--
